comment._content:
My elderly father claims that his father picked up a lifeboat of survivors from the SS Marina (which was torpedoed along with the SS City of Benares) just off Tory Island.  They'd been at sea for 8 (?) days.

I can't find anything about this on the internet.  Any idea how I can find out more about it - I tried searching the National Archives site but I'm a bit confused by all the different sections.

Thanks,
Trish

comment.author: 31575009@N05
comment._content:
See the comment (and link to Wikipedia) above. Like the SS City of Benares, the SS Marina was sunk by U-48 on the night of the 17th September 1940.

The confusion of lifeboats from the two ships led to one being left behind by HMS Hurricane which rescued the others. I concur with TVL 1970 that this image shows that lifeboat being "sighted from the air". The pilot's sighting led to the rescue of the lifeboat by HMS Anthony. Presumably your grandfather served aboard one of those two vessels.

comment.author: 75337124@N00
comment._content: Thanks, I'd read that article but the lifeboat I'm talking about wasn't from the SS City of Benares it was from the SS Marina. HMS Hurricane didn't pick up all the lifeboats from the SS Marina either. My grandfather was captain of a merchant ship transporting cargo around Ireland and decided to go around Tory Island on a whim when he spotted the light from an oil lamp bobbing in the sea and went to investigate; it was a lifeboat of survivors from the SS Marina. Anyway I just asked my Dad if he knew the name of my grandfather's ship - he reeled off some possibilities, one of which was the 'Carlingford' and then I found several mentions of it on the web Workd War 2 Day by Day - Day 384 Sept 18th 1940 and SS Marina. Dad says his father and the master of the SS Marina (Richard Townshend Payne) got on quite well and Dad remembers Payne visiting their house in Portstewart shortly after. Unfortunately his ship, SS Empire Prairie was torpedoed in 1942 with all hands lost.
